[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.version] [Integer overflow] Can an attacker manipulate the version field (i64) to cause integer overflow when converting to/from u64 transaction versions used internally, potentially allowing replay attacks or state corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.version] [Negative value injection] Since version is i64 (signed), can negative version numbers be injected into BigQuery, breaking ordering assumptions and allowing transactions to be queried/displayed out of sequence? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.version] [Replay attack] Is the version field validated against the actual blockchain state before insertion, or can an attacker inject duplicate version numbers to create false transaction records in BigQuery for fraudulent analytics? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.version] [Type mismatch] Does the i64 version field properly handle the u64 version numbers from Aptos blockchain without truncation or sign extension bugs that could cause version collisions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.version] [Monotonicity violation] Can out-of-order version insertions occur due to race conditions in the streaming pipeline, breaking the monotonic version guarantee and allowing historical transaction tampering? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.block_height] [Negative height injection] Can negative block_height values (i64 is signed) be injected, causing queries that filter by block height to return incorrect results or skip critical security-relevant transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.block_height] [Fork detection bypass] Is there validation that block_height is consistent with version number, or can an attacker inject mismatched block_height/version pairs to hide fork events in analytics? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.block_height] [Integer overflow] Can block_height overflow when converting from internal u64 representation, causing blocks to appear earlier than they actually occurred and breaking temporal analysis? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.block_height] [Genesis block attack] Can block_height=0 or block_height=-1 be injected for non-genesis transactions to manipulate historical queries or break indexing assumptions? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.hash] [Hash collision injection] Since hash is an unvalidated string field, can an attacker inject duplicate or malformed transaction hashes to create false positive matches in BigQuery queries used for fraud detection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.hash] [Hash format manipulation] Is the hash string validated to be a valid hex-encoded transaction hash, or can arbitrary strings be injected to cause SQL injection-like attacks in BigQuery queries? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.hash] [Case sensitivity bypass] Are hash comparisons case-sensitive in BigQuery queries, or can an attacker inject hashes with different casing to evade detection while maintaining uniqueness constraints? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.hash] [Hash length violation] Can truncated or extended hash strings be inserted, breaking downstream systems that assume fixed-length transaction identifiers? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.hash] [Special character injection] Can the hash field contain special characters, Unicode, or null bytes that break BigQuery parsing or cause query injection vulnerabilities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.type] [Type enumeration bypass] Since type is stored as an unrestricted string, can attackers inject invalid transaction types not recognized by Aptos to bypass analytics filters or cause parsing errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.type] [Type confusion attack] Can the type field be manipulated to misclassify transactions (e.g., marking a user transaction as a genesis transaction) to evade security monitoring? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.type] [SQL injection via type] Can malicious SQL fragments be injected through the type string field to execute unauthorized queries in BigQuery? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.type] [Case manipulation] Are transaction type comparisons case-sensitive, allowing attackers to inject 'USER' vs 'user' to evade exact-match filters? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.payload] [Payload injection attack] Since payload is optional and unrestricted, can arbitrarily large payloads be injected to cause BigQuery storage exhaustion or query timeouts? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.payload] [Sensitive data leakage] Is the payload field properly sanitized before BigQuery insertion, or can it leak sensitive transaction data like private keys or user credentials? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.payload] [Malformed payload parsing] Can malformed JSON/binary payloads cause deserialization vulnerabilities or crash BigQuery streaming processes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.payload] [Null vs empty distinction] Does the optional payload field properly distinguish between None and Some(''), or can this ambiguity cause incorrect transaction interpretations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.payload] [Script injection] Can the payload contain malicious Move bytecode or scripts that get logged to BigQuery and later executed if improperly parsed by analytics tools? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.state_change_hash] [State commitment forgery] Can the state_change_hash be manipulated to point to a different state root than what was actually committed, allowing fabricated state proofs in analytics? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.rs] [Field: Transaction.state_change_hash] [Hash mismatch attack] Is there validation that state_change_hash matches the actual state changes, or can inconsistent hashes be inserted to hide malicious state transitions? (High)
